ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SPECIALIST TEACHERS FOR
PHYSICALLY HANDICAPPED CHILDREN
(Availability of)


    1. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Education how many teachers have been specially trained to teach physically handicapped children, and whether more of such teachers will be available to voluntary organisations established to care for handicapped children.

    The Minister of State for Education (Dr Lee Chiaw Meng) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, to date ten teachers have been specially trained to teach physically handicapped children. Two specially trained teachers have just been appointed and another teacher has returned with specialist training. Arrangements have been made to post these three specialist teachers to the relevant voluntary organisations.

    Two more teachers are at present undergoing training in overseas institutions, and they are expected to complete their training some time this year.

Column: 774



    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Minister of State consider the number of available teachers adequate for the needs of the institutions which care for physically handicapped children?

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Mr Speaker, Sir, in his original question the Member for Katong has only asked for those who have been specially trained. However, I am able to say that, in addition to this number, there are some 22 other teachers who have also been seconded to various voluntary organisations.

Column: 774

EMPLOYMENT OF PERSONS
FROM SOCIAL WELFARE
INSTITUTIONS


    2. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Social Affairs what efforts have been made to find employment for persons who have been discharged from approved schools and homes of the Social Welfare Department or who are under probation.

    The Minister for Social Affairs (Inche Othman Bin Wok): Mr Speaker. Sir, the Social Welfare Department operates 12 residential institutions. However, as the Member's question is concerned with employment, consideration need not be

Column: 775

given to three of these institutions, namely, Perak House, the Welfare School for Boys at Keppel Road, and Woodlands Home, as the residents therein are either too young or too old for employment. Of the remaining nine institutions, one is an approved school (Gimson School) for young male offenders up to 19 years old; three (Toa Payoh Girls' Home, the Muslim Women's Welfare Home and Mount Emily Girls' Home) are approved homes and places of safety for women and girls up to 21 years old; three (Bukit Batok Boys' Hostel, Pasir Panjang Boys' Hostel and Canning Rise Girls' Hostel) are hostels for youths who have no proper home to go to after they are discharged from Social Welfare institutions or placed on probation by the Courts; and two (Bushey Park Home and Woodstock Home) are homes for destitute persons.

    The Social Welfare Department employs three Aftercare Officers and other ancillary staff to look after the welfare of discharged residents. During the past five years, some 611 persons discharged from Social Welfare homes were placed in gainful employment. The number of such persons who found employment has increased each year, from 96 in 1966, 101 in 1967, 112 in 1968, 146 in 1969 to 156 in 1970.

    For the youths and boys, the main type of work found for them is manual work, which includes casual labourers, shop assistants, hawker assistants, petrol kiosk attendants, sweepers, lorry attendants, factory operatives, etc. A few have been placed in semi-skilled jobs such as welders, greasers and motor mechanics.

    For the women and girls, the two main types of work found for them are domestic help and factory operatives. Other types of work found for them include seamstresses, clinic assistants, building labourers, eating-stall assistants, clerks, police trainees, telephone operatives, petrol kiosk attendants, hotel and cafe waitresses, salesgirls, book-binders, etc.

Column: 776



    For the destitute adults, our officers have encountered difficulties in placing them in employment because of their poor physical and mental condition. Many of them are also quite indifferent or unwilling to work, and the Social Welfare Department is doing everything possible to motivate them and to get them accustomed to work by organising them into work squads.

    With regard to the second part of the question on the employment of those under probation, the care and supervision of juvenile and adult offenders placed on probation are the statutory responsibilities of the Probation and Aftercare Department of my Ministry. The Probation of Offenders Ordinance provides the Courts with an alternative method of dealing with offenders who might otherwise have to be committed to a corrective or penal institution. This method involves the conditional suspension of punishment while the offender is released under the care and supervision of a probation officer. The probation system has over the years proved to be an effective method of rehabilitating selected offenders of both sexes and of all age groups.

    I am happy to say that at any one time at least 80 per cent of the adult probationers are gainfully employed. In respect of the employment of juvenile probationers, the employment rate is very much lower, at about 40 per cent. More often than not, the juvenile probationer is too young for employment. In such cases every attempt is made by the probation officer to secure the probationer's connection with youth clubs and generally in useful pre-occupations.

Column: 776

PHYSICALLY HANDICAPPED
PERSONS
(Training and employment)


    3. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Social Affairs (a) whether adequate facilities exist for physically handicapped persons to receive such training as will fit them for some type of employment; (b) what help is given to such persons towards obtaining employment; and (c) if he will consider

Column: 777

introducing the necessary legislation to provide employment opportunities for physically handicapped persons who have received appropriate training.

    Inche Othman Bin Wok: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government has a scheme to assist persons who become disabled through accident or disease. This scheme, which is administered by the Ministry of Labour, provides training for disabled persons in order to enable them to regain their economic independence. Training is normally given for a period of six months initially, and this may be extended for a further three months. A monthly subsistence allowance of $30 to $50 is payable to each trainee. Tuition fees and cost of materials are provided, where necessary. In 1970, 31 disabled persons benefited from this scheme.

    Many voluntary organisations are engaged in welfare work among the physically handicapped groups, such as the blind, the deaf, the spastic, the paraplegics, and so on. The services they provide are mainly educational, although some of these organisations also have vocational training facilities for those physically handicapped persons who are in the employable age group. These organisations run training centres and sheltered workshops. However, these training centres and workshops are still in the process of development and consequently the number of physically handicapped persons they can cope with is limited. In 1970, approximately 950 physically handicapped children and 100 adults received special education and training at some 15 schools, training centres and sheltered workshops. The voluntary organisations are doing a good job in this field.

    It is difficult to say whether the existing training facilities are adequate or otherwise, as statistics are still being compiled on the number of physically handicapped persons who require such training. The Social Welfare Department has set up a Rehabilitation Unit to liaise with the voluntary organisations,

Column: 778

to help in the compilation of such statistics, and to consider the need for expanding existing training facilities. The unit is in the process of compiling a central register of handicapped persons in order to obtain relevant data for planning purposes.

    The Rehabilitation Unit of the Social Welfare Department is presently exploring ways and means by which physically handicapped persons could be rehabilitated. Every encouragement and assistance is being given by the Department to voluntary organisations to enable them to expand their training facilities. In 1970, a sum of $622,057 was expended in assisting voluntary welfare organisations. This sum comprised $341,457 in the form of grants and $280,600 in the form of salaries for 32 teachers and nine instructors in voluntary institutions catering for handicapped groups. The unit is also introducing an employment placement service for physically handicapped persons.

    As to the second part of the question, Mr Speaker, Sir, a number of Government departments and voluntary welfare organisations are doing whatever they can to help physically handicapped persons find suitable employment. However, their efforts in this direction have not been altogether successful. There are a number of reasons for this, one of which is the prejudice among many employers who, for one reason or other, are reluctant to employ physically handicapped persons.

    In the course of the next few months I hope to make a series of visits to factories with a view to seeing what opportunities exist and what could further be done to secure employment for handicapped persons in industries.

    In answer to the last part of the question, Sir, it is not possible to say at this stage whether the Government will consider introducing legislation to provide for the compulsory employment of physically handicapped persons who have received the appropriate training. Once we know the extent of this problem, and if it is found that, on a voluntary basis, it cannot be resolved, legislation may be considered, as has

Column: 779

been introduced in many countries. It is hoped, however, that even without compulsion employers will themselves offer employment opportunities to the less fortunate among us.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim (Kallang): Sir, in view of the fact that about 800 industrial workers annually become disabled because of industrial injuries will the Minister for Social Affairs consider expanding the rehabilitation centres for such persons and, when it is completed, transfer such responsibilities to the Ministry of Labour?

    Inche Othman Wok: Sir, as I have said at the beginning of my answer, this comes under the portfolio of my colleague, the Minister for Labour. Perhaps he can explain to the Member.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Rajaratnam, would you like to explain?

    The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not aware of what the question is!

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: In view of the fact that about 800 industrial workers have become disabled because of industrial injuries, will the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour consider expanding the rehabilitation centres for such persons with a view to obtaining employment for them?

    Mr Rajaratnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, we are prepared to consider anything, but I cannot tell the Member at the moment what the result will be.

    Mr S. Ramaswamy (Potong Pasir): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0104 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 2006.

    I am moving this amendment in order to bring to the notice of this House that the toilet adjacent to the Stamp Office on the ground floor of the Supreme Court building is dirty and also smells. I understand it is being used by the public. I notice that the Government is prosecuting private firms and the public for not keeping their toilets clean. But the courts which impose a fine on these people are themselves not keeping their toilets in the building clean. They appear to be breaching the law. I wonder who will prosecute those who are responsible for maintaining this building. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, you will have noticed that a new feature in this House - whether desirable or undesirable I do not know - is the increasing interest shown by some Members in toilet attendants and toilet conditions. May 1 say at this stage that I am not in charge of the courts. There are two toilets in the Supreme Court building, one on the first floor and the other on the ground floor. These two toilets are used not only by litigants but also by numerous witnesses to cases in court and by members of the public. It is, therefore, difficult to prevent these persons from dirtying the toilets, short of employing a full-time attendant. But even an attendant will

Column: 781

be of little use unless be follows these persons into, the toilets. I understand that the present cleaning contractor cleans these toilets twice daily, once in the morning and once in the afternoon. Arrangements have since been made to have the toilets cleaned three times a day. I hope that satisfies the Member for Potong Pasir.

    Head 0107 -

    Dr Augustine H. H. Tan (Whampoa): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, That the sum to be allocated for Head 0107 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 2003.

    I am very concerned about the drastic reduction in the provision of bursaries and other assistance for students of higher institutions by $521,500. In the Memorandum on the Estimates of Revenue and Expenditure, it is explained that this reduction is partially offset by provision for "industrial development scholarships", "scholarships, fellowships and .training courses" and "printing", though I cannot imagine how printing can substitute for bursaries! The Memorandum also mentions study loans. I would like to know, Sir, how much is being made available for study loans and the terms and conditions for the award of such loans. I would think that some provision is also necessary for special loans to students to help them support their families while they are studying. One comes across too many cases, Sir, where bright students have had to give up their studies even though they have scholarships or bursaries, because their families rely on them for financial support. I speak with some authority on the subject, Sir, because I very nearly became a casualty my.

Column: 782

self. Fortunately, when I went to study for my Ph.D, under a fellowship, I was given an additional amount to help support my family.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, at a time when our economy is booming, it would seem to me to be unwarranted to reduce expenditure on such essential things as bursaries and scholarships. We should not only be increasing the number of awards available but also actively consider new schemes to enable people from poor families to obtain better education. The handicaps to the poor students are already tremendous, if one thinks of the over-crowded living conditions and the cultural poverty of their homes, in addition to the financial hardships.

    Every bit of talent that we can salvage will be an asset to Singapore. We can hold our heads proudly when we can truly say that no one is poor because of undeveloped talents or lack of opportunity. I would like to see, therefore, greater efforts being made in future years to ensure the greatest possible scope for human development. Sir, I beg to move.

    The Minister of Defence (Dr Goh Keng Swee) (for the Prime Minister): Sir, there has been a change in the system of awarding bursaries since some three years ago. Until then the award of bursaries was partly based on merit - the performance of the students --and partly based on the financial circumstances of their families. The result was quite unsatisfactory because the two do not necessarily go together. The present position is to award bursaries strictly on the performance of the students, that is, on merit. The bursaries are awarded to the value of anything from $750 to $1,500 or $2,000 a year. On the other hand, we have taken into account that there may be students who are not of outstanding ability but who, nevertheless, can perform reasonably well in the universities and whose families may be in straitened circumstances. For such students we offer loans. Over the last three years. There have been something like a hundred loans offered under the scheme to the value of around $500 a year.

Column: 783



    Whether one should take into account the putative loss of earnings to the family by reason of a student's going to the university instead of finding a job is, I think, a new principle. I do not know which country compensates families for this kind of loss of possible earnings. I doubt if there are any. I myself do not think that this is warranted under the circumstances for two reasons. First, I do not believe that in Singapore there has been a loss of brain power of high calibre by reason of the poverty of the families. The bursaries, the wide range of Colombo Plan and other scholarships to universities abroad, ensure that any outstanding students will have the best opportunities to get the most suitable form of university education. I have made a point of inquiring into the background of scholars who have returned from overseas courses on Colombo Plan or other scholarships. I have also made the point, when interviewing young administrative cadet officers and other Government personnel on their entry into the service, to inquire into their family background. It is astonishing that the vast majority, of these young men and women who have performed extremely well in the university here in Singapore came from very humble family background. For the most part, their fathers would be in occupations such' as cooks, taxi drivers or mechanics. Those with more affluent occupations would be minor contractors and Chinese medicine men. This provides strong evidence that in our society no school boy need be deprived of the highest educational opportunities because of the poverty of his family. Of course, now that we have national service and now that Higher School Certificate boys have to do two and a half years' service in the army, if the family is in straitened circumstances, one very good way of getting a university education and earning an income at the same time would be to take a regular commission, when the boy can do his degree course in the University while holding a commission as a Lieutenant or Second Lieutenant earning something like $500 or $600 a month

Head 0108 -

    Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0108 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1028.

    Sir, the estimate is for Office Boys (Supernumerary). The Concise Oxford Dictionary that I referred to gives the meaning of supernumerary as "in excess of the normal number". In the estimates for 1969-70, the number of office boys asked for under this category was one person. In the estimates for 1970-71, the request was for five supernumerary office boys. The Audit Department has also requested this year for seven supernumerary general clerical assistants. In each and every instance, a token vote of $10 has been asked for and granted up to now, last year and the year before last. Sir, it seems strange to me that year after year the number of office boys required has been progressively increased. If there is a real and increasing need for office boys, there should have been some systematic arrangement for recruiting office boys as such. I do not seriously think that there is a shortage of applicants for jobs as office boys. But if there is no real need for office boys, it is rather misleading to provide for an increasing number of supernumerary office boys under a token vote.

    Sir, my question is whether it is necessary to increase the number of supernumerary office boys under a token vote and what is the real significance, if any, in such increase in number?

Column: 785



    Mr E. W. Barker: Sir, the answer to the Member's question is national service. This is one of the side effects of national service and this token provision of $10 is merely to meet the need for the employment of office boys temporarily to replace those permanently recruited office boys who may be required to do their national service.

    Mr N. Govindasamy: Sir, as I have said, the number of office boys required has increased from one to five to seven from one year to the next, and the Department is asking for only $l0. How can they ever replace these office boys who go for national service with a $10 token vote? Do they want the office boys or do they not?

I think appropriately, not a subject for question by this House. note gladly that an increase of $153,850 under personal emoluments will be for the provision of 20 new posts to cope with additional audit, such as the People's Association audit and the Economic Development Board audit, and so on. It is possible that the staff requirements necessary for an extension of the functions of the Auditor-General's Department may be difficult to come by. I hope that every effort will be made to overcome any difficulties that may stand in the way of the Auditor-General's exercising his proper functions as completely and as freely as possible.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would just like to seek clarification on a small point. According to the Memorandum on the Estimates of Revenue and Expenditure. It is stated that one reason that accounts for the bigger vote required is that "the Department would like to conduct special investigation which would examine such problems as wastage and effectiveness." Sir, problems such as wastage and effectiveness, I should have thought, are already being looked after by the Organisation and Methods Branch of the Treasury and duplication of the same service surely will only result in wastage. Can the Minister please clarify?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee (for the Prime Minister): The Member for Katong wants to know whether the powers of the Auditor-General should not be extended to all statutory authorities and all enterprises wholly owned by the Government. In regard to statutory authorities, it may or may not be appropriate for the Auditor-General to audit

Column: 787

the accounts. This is usually provided for in the Ordinance establishing the particular authority.

    As regards enterprises wholly owned by the Government such as the Neptune Orient Lines and Chartered Industries, they are run purely on commercial lines and I do not think that the Auditor-General can do a better job than a professional firm of auditors. The Auditor-General does not employ qualified accountants, and his job is not to see whether departments or the authority is run on proper commercial lines. His main function is to ensure that public funds are spent with proper covering approval and in accordance with procedures laid down. For instance, if a particular department spends $5 million on flowers and flower pots, it is not the business of the Auditor-General to observe that this is a waste of public funds if that particular expenditure appears in the estimates and has been approved by Members. All he has to see is that the expenditure has the covering approval in the estimates passed by Parliament and the method of purchase is in accordance with financial procedures.

    In the case of a company auditor doing the accounts of Neptune Orient Lines or Chartered Industries, he has to make sure as well that expenditures are properly incurred which will increase the profitability or efficiency of the business. There are two separate concepts of auditing.

    As regards the inquiry by the Member for Ulu Pandan -

    An hon. Member: The Member for Jalan Kayu!

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I am sorry. He is the Member for Jalan Kayu. Sir, Parliament meets so infrequently that it is quite a task to remember which constituency belongs to which Member.

Column: 788



    The Auditor-General will take into account waste incurred, for instance, in disposal of stores and whether the disposal of surplus stores has been done properly. He observes. He takes note whether waste is incurred in this sense.

    The responsibility of the Organisation and Methods Branch is rather different. They will consider whether the staff is adequate or surplus to the requirements of a department or a Ministry. They will see whether responsibilities and duties are fairly shared among officers in the department. They look into questions like the most suitable type of equipment, typewriters, adding machines or whatever is requested by a department or Ministry. By and large, they are not concerned with waste incurred in the day-to-day accounting or day-to-day running of departments and Ministries.

    + Amendment No. (4) reads as follows:

    Sir, the creation of an Anti-Pollution Unit is a timely and wise move. The fact that this unit is placed under the direct supervision of the Prime Minister reflects the importance of the pollution problem. This is especially so when Singapore is now undergoing a transformation through the process of industrialisation and urbanisation. Although the environmental problems in our

Column: 789

island state have not yet reached a state of gravity, it is, of course, very logical for us to tackle the problems early if we are to avoid the environmental crises that other developed countries have to face. Sir, in this connection, Members of the House would like to know from the Prime Minister about all the necessary measures he will take to deal with the problem of pollution, and whether he will send abroad a senior official of the Anti-Pollution Unit to study the latest technique of dealing with this matter. Sir, I beg to move.

    Mr N. Govindasamy: Sir, while I welcome the setting up of the Anti-Pollution Unit, I must express some dissatisfaction with the manner in which the implementation of our Anti-Pollution Campaign has been carried out this far. It is my hope that the proposed unit will help to remove the cause of my dissatisfaction. I have, however, to seek further clarification about the unit as I have noted that the sum of $164,230 has been allocated for the 17 staff in the unit. My questions are:

    (1) Has this unit been set up yet? If so, where does it operate from?

    (2) What are the functions of the unit?
